Este es un espacio textil digital testim: This is a testimonial digital textile space. Get ready to listen and connect with the senses of reconciliation that reside here. There are many ways to experience and travel these paths. You can take shortcuts, but you must take the time to listen.A linear reading will give you a general idea of this territory, the connections will reveal themselves as you allow yourself to be touched by the embroidered stories.
Los Tiempos de la Escucha es una exposic: The Time(s) to Listen is an exhibition that invites us to connect with two textile collectives made up of women who have suffered the experiences of the war in Colombia, along with their feelings and testimonies regarding the question; what shapes can reconciliation take? It is an opportunity to discover whispers , textures, colors and nuances that interweave textile and digital languages, to understand the ways in which the women imagine the paths and actions required to make peace possible in a country that is still at war. It is an invitation to prepare the body for listening, to measure the times that this demands and to reflect upon the power it has. The Time(s) to Listen was brought to life by the union between a transdisciplinary research team from Bogotá and Medellín, and the women's collectives of Sonsón, Quibdó, Bojayá and Mampuján, who have for years embroidered, woven or sewn their memories about the damage caused by the armed conflict and imagined ways to mend life. The hand-crafted textiles and digital explorations came together to bring life to this exhibition, which in turn seeks to amplify the women’s stories and thereby invite us to be touched by what they share and teach.
Guayacán Artesanías es un colectivo de m: Guayacán Crafts (Guayacán Artesanías) is a collective of Afro and indigenous women from Bellavista, the municipal capital of Bojayá, which at the end of the 1980s started out as a Grassroots Ecclesiastic Community (CEB) supported by the Sisters of the Augustinian Missionary and Father Jorge Luis Mazo. Craft practices such as embroidery, knitting, crochet and baking gradually turned the women into a group who could resist the effects of the war on their territories through textile and craft practices.
Pieza emblemática_ Nuestras víctimas, 2: Emblematic piece_ Our victims, 2nd May 2002, Bellavista – Bojayá, Chocó. Making history, embroidering memory, (2003). Tapestry embroidered with the names of the fatalities of the massacre of May 2, 2002 accompanied with flowers, animals, boats and trades typical of the region. Elaborated by the women with the support of the Augustinian Missionary Sisters and the Choibá Crafts group from the city of Quibdó. It is exhibited every year during the commemoration of the massacre in order to remember and denounce those responsible. It has played a fundamental role in the process of the exhumation of the dead by serving as a document of remembrance for the relatives. It measures 6 m. by 2.5 m.  Textile technique: Embroidery, sewing and painting on canvas.
Este Telón de la Reconciliación es una p: This Reconciliation Hand-embroidered cloth is a piece made by the women of the Artesanías Guayacán collective in May 2019. It is a fabric with yellow background that contains depictions of scenes and images of the daily life along the Atrato river, which the women embroidered as a representation of the feelings they associate with the word reconciliation. The development consisted, first, in a collective composition in which each member of the group contributed their idea so that Daisy Chana Picama, one of the indigenous members and the youngest of the group, could draw it. Using songs and verses, memories of the river and of chirimías (traditional songs), images of plantain trees, rice and elderberry crops, the women created an Atrato-like landscape, which had passed through everyone’s hands in order to, stitch by stitch, bring life to the shapes of reconciliation that sustains and strengthens them.

Mujeres Tejiendo Sueños y Sabores de Paz: Women Weaving Dreams and Flavours of Peace Mampuján is a textile collective who since 2004, four years after being forcibly displaced from their villages in the municipality of María La Baja in the region of Montes de María, have not stopped sewing to claim and build peace.
Desplazamiento: Mampuján día de llanto (: Displacement: Mampuján day of crying (2004)_ This tapestry was the first piece created by the collective. It illustrates the events that took place during the March 10, 2000 displacement, and depicts scenes of violence against the population by the paramilitaries. In spite of the pain and tears, with this first tapestry, the women of Mampuján began to tell their story and thus realised that "the only way to heal themselves was to remember: to deal with the memories, to narrate them, to crush them and to rebuild them until they no longer hurt" (Anadolu, 2018). Technique: Appliqué or ‘fabric on fabric’, a technique that uses shapes cut from scraps of fabric sewnin layers.
TEJEDORAS DE SUEÑOS Y SABORES DE PAZ | M: WOMEN WEAVING DREAMS AND FLAVOURS OF PEACE | BOJAYÁ, CHOCÓ_
Cerca de 20 integrantes del grupo de Tej: About 20 members of the group Tejedoras de Sueños y Sabores de Paz, inhabitants of the municipality of María Baja, meet one afternoon in May 2019 at the evangelical church in the neighborhood of el Recreo to collectively answer: What shape does reconciliation have? A conversation arises between them about the flavours, smells, sounds and textures that this word could hold. There’s laughter and anecdotes, recipes for turrón (nougat), coffee and mondongo (tripe soup), sweet, bitter and salty flavours that evoke the idea of foods favored in the region. The longing for music and dance becomes present, as well as the sounds that bring news and become omens. The ideas and drawings that are shared inspire the creation of the patchwork. Little by little, the shapes of a pot and the fire that represents the slow process of cooking arise. What flavours and dreams of reconciliation could the women be preparing?
